title: Linux Fundamentals: CLI, Core Components, Packaging, and Ubuntu Server VM

questions.text: `pwd` prints your current working directory and is useful when you’re lost in the filesystem.
questions.answer: True. `pwd` reports the absolute path of the shell’s current working directory.

questions.text: `ls -la` shows a long listing and includes hidden dotfiles.
questions.answer: True. `-l` enables the long format and `-a` includes entries starting with `.`.

questions.text: `cd -` changes to your home directory.
questions.answer: False. `cd` (with no args) goes home; `cd -` jumps back to the previous directory.

questions.text: `mkdir -p` can create parent directories that don’t exist yet.
questions.answer: True. `-p` makes missing parents and does not error if the directory already exists.

questions.text: `rmdir` removes directories recursively, including non-empty ones.
questions.answer: False. `rmdir` only removes *empty* directories; use `rm -r` for recursive removal.

questions.text: On Linux, `touch file.txt` can update a file’s timestamp even if the file already exists.
questions.answer: True. `touch` creates an empty file if missing, otherwise updates timestamps.

questions.text: `rm -i` is safer than plain `rm` because it prompts before each removal.
questions.answer: True. Interactive mode reduces “oops I nuked the wrong thing” incidents.

questions.text: `cp -a` is commonly used when you want to preserve metadata while copying.
questions.answer: True. Archive mode preserves permissions, timestamps, symlinks, symlink-ness, and more.

questions.text: A symlink is created with `ln target linkname`, while a hard link uses `ln -s`.
questions.answer: False. Hard link: `ln target linkname`; symlink: `ln -s target linkname`.

questions.text: `less` is a pager that lets you search inside a file interactively.
questions.answer: True. You can search with `/pattern` and move through matches with `n`.

questions.text: `tail -f` is useful for following logs as they are appended.
questions.answer: True. `-f` keeps the file open and streams new lines as they arrive.

questions.text: `wc -l` counts the number of lines in a file or stream.
questions.answer: True. `-l` counts lines (other common flags are `-w` words and `-c` bytes).

questions.text: `uniq` removes all duplicates in a file regardless of position.
questions.answer: False. `uniq` only removes *adjacent* duplicates, so you usually `sort` first.

questions.text: `tr` is used for character-level transforms like lower→upper or squeezing repeated spaces.
questions.answer: True. It operates on characters, not structured fields.

questions.text: `sed 's/\./-/g'` replaces dots with dashes globally in the input stream.
questions.answer: True. `s/old/new/g` performs a substitution on each line, with `g` for all matches.

questions.text: `grep -iE "warn|fail|error" file` does a case-insensitive extended-regex search.
questions.answer: True. `-i` ignores case and `-E` enables extended regex alternation with `|`.

questions.text: `find . -type d` searches for directories.
questions.answer: True. `-type d` restricts results to directories (files would be `-type f`).

questions.text: `chmod 644 notes.txt` typically results in read/write for owner and read-only for group/others.
`umask` sets the maximum permissions a new file can have.
questions.answer: False. `umask` sets the *mask of permissions to remove* from defaults.

questions.text: `journalctl -b` shows logs for the current boot on systemd-based systems.
questions.answer: True. `-b` scopes the journal to the current boot session.

questions.text: `dmesg` primarily reads the kernel ring buffer (drivers/hardware messages).
questions.answer: True. It’s a kernel log view; piping through `grep -i error` is common.

questions.text: `ip addr` and `ip route` are modern tools for inspecting addresses and routing.
questions.answer: True. `ip` is the contemporary interface to kernel networking state.

questions.text: In the Linux stack, syscalls are the boundary between user space and the kernel.
questions.answer: True. Syscalls are the controlled interface apps use to request kernel services.

questions.text: The boot chain is a relay where firmware starts, a bootloader loads the kernel/initramfs, and the kernel launches the first userspace process.
questions.answer: True. That handoff ends when PID 1 is running in userspace.

questions.text: PID 1 is the first userspace process and acts as a service supervisor (often systemd).
questions.answer: True. PID 1 starts/monitors essential services and defines operational targets/runlevels.

questions.text: Userland includes libc, core utilities, and shells such as bash/zsh/fish.
questions.answer: True. This is the everyday toolkit above the kernel that makes the CLI usable.

questions.text: On modern Linux desktops, Wayland is a display protocol alternative to X11.
questions.answer: True. Wayland and X11 are the main display protocols; the rest layers above them.

questions.text: Linux security isolation can involve namespaces, cgroups, and LSMs like SELinux/AppArmor.
questions.answer: True. These are composable primitives that contribute to isolation and policy enforcement.

questions.text: Linux updates feel less disruptive partly because components are updated incrementally rather than replacing large subsystems.
questions.answer: True. Updates tend to be package/component-level, reducing “big bang” replacements.

questions.text: Linux rarely needs defragmenting because it never fragments at all.
questions.answer: False. Fragmentation can happen, but extent-based and delayed allocation designs keep it low in practice.

questions.text: Linux can delete a file that is still in use because removing the name does not remove the data until all file descriptors close.
questions.answer: True. The directory entry can be removed while the inode/data persists until the last reference is gone.

questions.text: `sudo` asks for your password after the command because it authenticates intent first and logs privileged actions for auditing.
questions.answer: True. `sudo` is designed for least-privilege elevation with accountability.

questions.text: `dpkg` is mainly responsible for repository metadata refresh and dependency resolution.
questions.answer: False. `dpkg` installs/tracks `.deb` packages; APT handles repos and dependency resolution.

questions.text: If an install is interrupted and you see 'dpkg was interrupted', `sudo dpkg --configure -a` is a standard recovery step.
questions.answer: True. It finishes configuring unpacked packages; often followed by `sudo apt -f install`.

questions.text: `apt update` upgrades installed packages to newer versions.
questions.answer: False. `apt update` refreshes package lists/metadata; `apt upgrade` performs upgrades.

questions.text: `apt full-upgrade` may remove packages to resolve dependency changes.
questions.answer: True. It’s allowed to remove packages when required to satisfy dependencies.

questions.text: `apt remove` and `apt purge` both uninstall a package, but `purge` also removes its configuration files.
questions.answer: True. `remove` keeps configs; `purge` deletes configs too.

questions.text: Installing a local `.deb` is often safer with `apt install ./thing.deb` than `dpkg -i` because APT can resolve and fetch dependencies.
questions.answer: True. `dpkg` won’t fetch missing deps; APT will.

questions.text: To build an Ubuntu Server VM lab in VirtualBox, the tutorial suggests a VM with 8 CPU cores, ~6 GB RAM, and ~10 GB disk.
questions.answer: True. Those settings are intentionally generous for a server lab and leave headroom for services.

questions.text: After the first boot, a quick sanity check includes `systemctl --failed` and a high-priority `journalctl` view to spot obvious errors.
questions.answer: True. `systemctl --failed` and `journalctl -p 3 -xb` help confirm nothing is ‘on fire’ post-install.
